conversation.message: Hello School_E Admissions—I'm Student_E and I’m formally applying to School_E as my first choice. Your program and community are the best fit for what I’m looking for, and I would commit to attending if accepted. Thank you for your consideration.

With identical priority lists at all schools and only one seat each, I have the lowest priority everywhere, so I need to secure the best possible outcome quickly. If any higher-priority students do not apply to School_E, I can be accepted; delaying would only reduce my chances.

conversation.message: Student_E, thank you for your application and for sharing how strongly you feel about School_E. Although Student_E is applying now and would commit, I have quota 1 and may be able to attract a higher-priority student (A–D) later if they do not receive offers from their top choices. Accepting Student_E now would lock my only seat and prevent matching with any higher-ranked student. Therefore, I should reject at this stage to preserve capacity for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message: Dear School_E Admissions, thank you again for considering my earlier application. conversation.message: Student_E, thank you for following up and for your continued interest in School_E. conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority ranks Student_E last. Since Student_E is only initiating [TALK] (not an [APPLY]) and has already been rejected once, the best move is to keep the option open: respond politely, indicate we cannot commit now, and invite them to re-apply later if still unmatched while signaling that offers depend on capacity/priority. This preserves flexibility to accept a higher-ranked student if they approach later.
